title: Denial of service in report view.

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
Hello Team!
First of all thank you for acknowledging my feature request, I know it will help a lot of users.

Description:
==========
I just wanted to report a potential vulnerability on the report view functionality.
For obvious reasons I'm using my sandboxed team on an alternate account to test it, but I'm pretty sure it can be still exploited on non-sandboxed teams.
I'm guessing that one of the main differences between sandboxed and non-sandboxed teams is that non-sandboxed have rate-limiting, but this wouldn't be a successfuly way of preventing this potential attack, but just a way of slowing it down, but not for long.

Basically the problem relies in that the view report functionality, tries to load every comment, either man made or system made, which, given enough comments, overloads the server and sends a 524 Origin Time-Out.

I was able to get this error by sending around 450 "test" messages on the same report, or by sending a few big messages. You can see it by yourself on reports 137508, 132450 and 138662 (Three different ways of exploiting this vulnerability)

Why is this a vulnerability?
======================
A malicious individual could very well leverage this vulnerability to prevent a legitimate user from accessing the report. In addition, it causes an unnecessary load on Hackerone's servers, since it can be used as a request amplification attack, by issuing a large amount of requests to the report, once it's filled with random info. Also, even though compression techniques can be used to reduce the amount of data transferred, this can by greatly bypassed by issuing high-entropy data (random), which would hinder the compression mechanisms.

How to fix this?
=============
Several ideas come to mind:
- Limit the amount of consecutive comments that can be seen at once in a report, providing a "see more" button which will at most overload the client interface, not the server.
- Limit the amount of data sent per comment, providing a "see more" button which loads the following chunk of data.
- When a high amount of comment load is detected (either because of a high amount of comments or big comments being sent), perform a CAPTCHA check.

As you can see on the following screenshot, the report failed to load: {F95556}

This is the request made by the Ajax controller: {F95557}

This is the response sent by the server, showing a gateway error after 60 seconds: {F95558}

activities.message:
O @apok, @apok, wherefor art thou @apok?
Deny thy account and refuse thy handle;
Or if thou wilt not, be but sworn my friend
And I'll no longer close this report as N/A

Actually, given the top quality writeup, and the fact that although we consider this more of a functional bug I can see where you're coming from regarding why we should address this, I think Informative makes more sense as a closure status. 

Basically, given that this only lets researchers sabotage reports that they already have legitimate access to, we don't consider a security vulnerability. Were you able to break reports that you _didn't_ create/get invited to, then we'd be much more worried.

Fare thee well,


Evan

activities.message:
Hahahaha, you guys are awesome.
No, but honestly: I seriously consider that someone who has legitimate access to a report, can break them. Please hear me out and consider the following scenarios:
- A disgruntled team member and/or bug bounty program member that wants to deny access to legitimate reports. This is something we often see in web applications that allow multiple access to certain objects of the application. Distrupting the access to legitimate users would cause a serious problem for the program and it would also cause a high load on your support channel.
- A researcher that created a report and wants to prevent access to it by other people. Considering we can add comments to publicly disclosed reports, we could prevent someone from accessing them.

Also, this is not the first time a fix/bounty has been issued for a vulnerability that prevents someone from seeing a report. Check this out:
- https://hackerone.com/reports/59369
- https://hackerone.com/reports/115205
- https://hackerone.com/reports/38232

Those are three reports that talk about denial of service attacks by users that already have access to them.

activities.message:
Hey @apok,

Thanks for your additional thought. Here's a little more elaboration on why we're not treating this as a security issue.
1) Protecting against rogue users with legitimate access harming their own content is generally beyond the purview of our bug bounty program. Therein lies madness. 
2) As you mentioned, worst case here is that the non-malicious users contact our support channel when they can't load the report, and then we fix it for them. This doesn't hide the report, it just makes its content unavailable.
3) A researcher hiding a publicly disclosed bug totally sucks, but again falls more under the category of functional bug than security risk.

In regards to the reports you linked for precedent, I knew about them, and admittedly that bothered me. This kinda bug is pretty close to the threshold of a legit vulnerability and even though we try really _really_ hard to be consistent, having different engineers coming on and off security duty means inevitable quirks like this. To make sure that doesn't happen again I started a larger conversation with the team, and the firm consensus was that this is a purely functional issue and we should stick to that going forwards. The second part of that is that we also have something of a trend of resolving and even rewarding the first report of a functional bug (even if we don't fix it immediately), so thankfully we've been even more consistent about not resolving reports of this nature in recent months. 

I hope that makes sense, and just let me know if you have any more questions.

Thanks!


Evan

activities.message:
Oh well, I won't deny that it is a bit dissapointing and I usually base myself on both previous reports and the bounty program guidelines, in order to measure the threshold that one must meet with a vulnerability so it can be considered. But then again, I'm sympathetic to what a growing community and maturing application means, so I understand why you chose not to consider this.

Also, while I was writing the recommendation, I was feeling sorry for the poor soul that had to implement the fix, it seemed like a big one.

As a final recommendation, can we maybe include this type of issue into the "Scope exclusions" so that everyone is aware that this shouldn't be something worth pursuing? Also if you agree, we could disclose this to avoid duplicates and to clarify this new policy.

Let me know what you think.
Kind Regards,
Apok

PD: I'm dying to know what the 2500$ bug is about! hahaha

activities.message:
I totally understand the disappointment, I'm not thrilled with it either, but I'm pretty sure it's the best of a bad bunch of outcomes (at least from our side, I guess your best outcome would probably be a ginormous bounty).

It's still a valid and annoying functional bug, so hopefully we'll rope someone into taking care of it someday. And in the meantime I've already filed a task to update our scope exclusions accordingly so no one else has to go through the same process. I'll also chat with some folks about disclosing this report - normally it wouldn't really qualify, but I think that you're right that it serve as a warning to other folks investigating this type of issue.

As for the $2500 bug, you'll just have to wait and see!
